required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Efficacy and Safety of Bile Salt Stimulated Lipase (BSSL) as Replacement Therapy in Infant Formula for Preterm Infants
clinical_study.official_title: A Prospective, Randomized, Double-blind Crossover Study Comparing 0.15 g/L rhBSSL Added to Infant Formula Versus Placebo During One Week of Treatment in Preterm Infants Born Before Week 32 of Gestational Age

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to evaluate the efficacy in preterm infants following treatment with BSSL when administered in infant formula.

detailed_description.textblock: In this double-blind crossover study, patients will be randomized to receive infant formula including BSSL or infant formula without BSSL for the first 7 days. After a wash-out period of 2 days the patients will "crossover" to the other treatment regimen and receive an additional 7 days treatment. The primary efficacy measurements will be made by collecting stool during the last three days of each treatment period.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Coefficient of Fat Absorption in stool
primary_outcome.time_frame: Stool collected for a 72-hour period during the final 3 days of each treatment period

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in length and body weight between the start and end of each treatment period
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and after one week of treatment

intervention.description: 0.15 g/L rhBSSL added to infant formula; one week treatment

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Preterm infants
- less than or equal to 32 weeks of gestational age
- appropriate for gestational age
- enterally fed with infant formula

clinical_study.keyword: BSSL is present in fresh mother's milk but not in infant formula.
